snippet: When government authorities chose not to prosecute HSBC on charges of vast and prolonged money laundering, they weakened deterrence for wrongdoing.
abstract: Editorial laments fact that federal and state authorities have chosen not to indict London-based bank HSBC on charges of vast and prolonged money laundering for fear that criminal prosecution would topple bank and endanger financial system; says if banks operating at center of global economy cannot be held accountable, solution is to break them up and restrict their activities, not shield them and their leaders from prosecution.
lead_paragraph: When government authorities chose not to prosecute HSBC on charges of vast and prolonged money laundering, they weakened deterrence for wrongdoing.
